description: From Middle English [Term?], borrowed from Old French triumphe, from Latin triumphus (“triumphal procession”), ultimately from Ancient Greek θρίαμβος (thríambos, “thriambus”). Doublet of thriambus and trump.

entries.meaning: A conclusive success following an effort, conflict, or confrontation of obstacles; victory; conquest.
examples: After being defeated in three previous finals, Roger finally tasted triumph' at this year's competition.

entries.meaning: A magnificent and imposing ceremonial performed in honor of a victor.
(obsolete) Any triumphal procession; a pompous exhibition; a stately show or pageant.
A state of joy or exultation at success.
examples: Hercules from Spain / Arrived in triumph, from Geryon slain.

entries.meaning: A card game, also called trump.
(historical, Ancient Rome) a ceremony held to publicly celebrate and sanctify the military achievement of an army commander.
A work of art, cuisine, etc. of very high quality.
examples: Scorsese's latest film is a triumph.
This wedding cake is a triumph.

entries.meaning: A card trick in which the cards are shuffled with half face-up and half face-down, then laid out so that only the observer's chosen card is facing upward.

verbs.description: triumph (third-person singular simple present triumphs, present participle triumphing, simple past and past participle triumphed)

entries.meaning: To celebrate victory with pomp; to rejoice over success; to exult in an advantage gained; to exhibit exultation.
examples: How long shall the wicked triumph?

entries.meaning: To prevail over rivals, challenges, or difficulties.
To succeed, win, or attain ascendancy.
examples: No one reckoned in advance that he had anything but a very testing job as host. He had to be tough, brave, witty, engaging – and decent. He triumphed on every count, thanks to sheer ability.
where commerce triumphed on the favouring gales

entries.meaning: To play a trump in a card game.
examples: Of the kings and the queens that triumph in the cards
